# setup the two repo workflow

- [ ] first explain this to me. Here is the workflow that I want to have.
I want to be able to use the issues here in the content creation repository as my content management system so to speak. Whenever I update an issue that has the label is post, I want this Repository to notify/update the hosting Repository. Is this the approach you're currently implementing?
ask agent, is this automated? if i update an issue, with a isPost label, will it automatically update/notify the hosting repo? via a webhook or another better option?

- [ ] what steps do i perform to get this to work in the hosting repository?

comments.body:
I'll summarize what I read and clarify which repo I'm currently working in.

**Summary**
- **Context:** You created a two-repo workflow: a hosting repo (`joshualinog/scribal.bible`) that serves the site, and a content repo (`joshualinog/scribal.bible-CONTENT-CREATION`) that stores issues-as-content and content-generation scripts.
- **Goal:** Convert labeled GitHub issues in the content repo into JSON + downloaded assets that the hosting repo (Eleventy site) can consume under `src/_data/posts/` and `src/assets/posts/<slug>/`.

**Which repo I am in**
- **Current workspace/repo:** `scribal.bible-CONTENT-CREATION` (the content repo). This is the repo shown in the current workspace context (branch `main`).
- **Other repo referenced:** `scribal.bible` (the hosting repo) — this is the site repo that will receive generated JSON/assets and serve the site.

**What the other agent (earlier assistant) shared / did**
- **Scripts and templates created (in the hosting repo workspace originally):**
  - `content-repo-template/generate-and-push.js` — Node.js script intended to run inside the content repo. It:
    - Uses `GITHUB_TOKEN` to read issues from the content repo.
    - Generates JSON files for posts into `src/_data/posts/`.
    - Downloads images into `src/assets/posts/<slug>/`.
    - Clones the hosting repo using a PAT and copies generated files there, then commits & pushes.
  - `.github/workflows/generate-and-push.yml` — workflow template to run on `issues` and `issue_comment` events in the content repo, calling the script and using a `HOSTING_PUSH_TOKEN` secret to push to the hosting repo.
  - README.md in the template explaining required secrets, PAT scopes, and setup/security guidance.
  - Also earlier templates/scripts for hosting-repo mode: `scripts/fetch-issues.js` and `.github/workflows/fetch-posts.yml` (these were the alternative approach to run in the hosting repo).
- **Recommended approach:** Option B — run generation inside the content repo (so it can read its issues with `GITHUB_TOKEN`) and push results to the hosting repo using a PAT (`HOSTING_PUSH_TOKEN`) stored in the content repo secrets.
- **Attempts & issues documented:**
  - You cloned the content repo locally but initially hit 403 permission errors when trying to push.
  - The assistant attempted to help copy files into the content repo but could not write directly without PAT or repo access.
  - An accidental commit of `content-scripts/generate-and-push.js` was pushed into the hosting repo (`scribal.bible`) by you; the assistant explained corrective options (revert, PR).
  - The assistant created `CONVERSATION-2025-11-13.md` in the hosting repo with the day’s transcript.
- **Options the assistant offered:**
  - Produce a `git-format-patch` of the template files or a zip to upload to a Codespace.
  - Provide exact shell commands to copy files into the content repo (requires a PAT).
  - Open a PR in the content repo (requires PAT or `gh` auth).
  - Prepare Codespace instructions and modify scripts to open PRs instead of pushing directly.

**Key decisions you made**
- You chose Option B (run in content repo and push to hosting repo).
- You intended to use a Codespace or local clone of the content repo to apply the templates.
- You asked the assistant to copy `generate-and-push.js` into the content repo but the assistant could not push without a PAT; you later cloned the content repo locally (with some auth trouble).

**What I can do next (pick one)**
- **Prepare a git-format-patch** of the template files so you can apply it in a Codespace or local clone (no PAT needed).
- **Create a zip** of the template files for upload into a Codespace.
- **Produce exact `git` + `gh` commands** to add the files to the content repo and open a PR (you’ll need to run them where you have auth).
- **Prepare a Codespace setup guide** with step-by-step commands to apply the templates, add the `HOSTING_PUSH_TOKEN` secret, and test the script locally.
- **Prepare a revert patch or PR** to remove the accidental file from the hosting repo.

Which of these should I do now? (You can reply with the number or name; I can create the patch/zip or the Codespace instructions right away.)

Proposed JSON schema for a Post:

Fields (recommended):
- id: number (issue number)
- title: string (issue title)
- slug: string (URL-safe slug)
- author: { login: string, id: number, url: string }
- created_at: string (ISO 8601, issue created_at)
- updated_at: string (ISO 8601, issue updated_at -> use as post date)
- body: string (issue body / main content)
- comments: [ { author: string, body: string, created_at: string } ]
- labels: [string] (all labels)
- tags: [string] (non-constructive labels to become tags)
- main_category: string (one primary category)
- post_type: string (e.g., article, video, gallery)
- media: [ { type: "image|video|file", filename: string, url: string, alt?: string } ]
- assets: [ { path: string, url: string } ]
- excerpt: string (short summary)
- draft: boolean (optional)
- custom: object (freeform for extra fields)

Example JSON:
{
  "id": 123,
  "title": "My Post Title",
  "slug": "my-post-title",
  "author": { "login": "alice", "id": 42, "url": "https://github.com/alice" },
  "created_at": "2025-11-07T12:00:00Z",
  "updated_at": "2025-11-08T09:30:00Z",
  "body": "# Markdown content...\nMore text...",
  "comments": [ { "author": "bob", "body": "Nice post", "created_at": "2025-11-08T10:00:00Z" } ],
  "labels": ["POST","isPost"],
  "tags": ["media","bible"],
  "main_category": "Psalms",
  "post_type": "article",
  "media": [ { "type": "image", "filename": "pic.jpg", "url": "assets/pic.jpg", "alt": "Caption" } ],
  "assets": [ { "path": "assets/pic.jpg", "url": "/assets/pic.jpg" } ],
  "excerpt": "Short summary.",
  "draft": false
}

Notes / considerations:
- Use issue number as stable id.
- Treat issue body as Markdown; preserve comments separately.
- Copy media files referenced in the issue into an assets folder and rewrite URLs to point at site assets.
- Use labels for both content selection (POST/isPost) and tags.
- Use updated_at as the canonical post date (as requested).
- Keep a 'custom' object for experiment fields without changing the schema.

If this looks good I can: 1) create a small script to fetch labeled issues and emit JSON files for Eleventy, or 2) add a GitHub Action to run the fetch on issue changes. Tell me which next.

# GENERAL CODE STRUCTURE AND STRATEGIES

i want this website to be a repository that hosts the codebase for a website at the url `scribal.bible`. i want to pull content for the website from a private called PRIVATEREPONAMEHERE. i want to build content for `scribal.bible` from the content in issues. i want to pull appropriate issues via a labeling system and heuristic.

i only want the site to be built with eleventy and serve static pages so its fast. i want it to be served on github pages via github actions. i want the build / deploy process to do these things: 

1. look for issues with the appropriate label scheme (possessing labels that are SITE-CONSTRUCTOR labels); the primary label will be POST. store these as data in json format.
2. download and store all those issues as data when:  any issue was updated, and then download it only if it is updated. OR if it is a new issue.
3. i need to appropriately understand the issue structure, so that i can determine the difference between the initial issue content and the following "comments" that follow.
4. i need the data store to be accessible for building the post pages.
5. i need to be able to post images, videos, and other media in the initial issue structure and "copy" these into the assets folder and appropriately link to the url scheme
6. each issue will correspond to a "post" essentially. the site will have hundreds of posts, and will be a like a media-rich blog/vlog.
7. each post will get a page.
8. i need a url scheme and pagination.
9. i will have several types of content-posts, and i need to create basic types and then have associated templates built in nunjucks and appropriate includes for each post-type.
10. I will need to have ca
11. i need NON-CONSTRUCTIVE labels (labels not used for pulling site content) to be pulled, read, and stored as "tags".
12. i need each post to have a main category.
13. i need the date the issue/post with POST label is updated to be the date of the json object.
14. i need the PRIVATEREPONAMEHERE to be private. should we use secrets? don't know.
